sec.p: ABSTRACT

Early blight disease (EB),
Alternaria alternata
, is destructive on
Solanum lycopersicum Mill.
The responses of 35 domestic and exotic commercial tomato genotypes to early blight were examined at transplanting and maturing stages using genetic diversity analysis, with 15 Inter Simple Sequence Repeat (ISSR) primers, total phenolic content (TPC), and enzymatic activity of catalase (CAT), phenylalanine ammonia lyase (PAL), peroxidase (POD) and superoxide dismutase (SOD) assays. The disease severity ranged from 18 to 87.5%. Eleven of 15 ISSR primers generated 68 loci of which 63 (90%) were polymorphic. Polymorphism information content value varied from 0.3 to 0.5 with an average of 0.4. Neiâ€™ s measure of the average gene diversity ranged from 0.06 to 0.5. The Tomato genotypes were divided into five clusters in Un-weighted Pair Group Method with Arithmetic Mean (UPGMA) analysis, showing a considerable similarity between resistance level and molecular classification pattern. Antioxidant analysis indicated a significant increase in TPC and CAT, POD, PAL and SOD activities in most inoculated tomato genotypes at both growth stages. The highest increase in activity was seen in PAL (5- fold) and TPC (4-fold) at transplanting stage, whereas the highest TPC (2 to 3-fold) and POD activity (3-fold) were found at maturing stage in all the inoculated resistant genotypes in comparison with controls. Esfahan Local and H . a.s 2274 showed the highest level of activity in POD (2.5- and 3- fold, respectively) and TPC (2.5- and 4- fold, respectively). Our results suggest that using both genetic diversity and enzymatic diversity as markers, it is possible to discriminate resistant from susceptible tomato genotypes to early blight disease.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
This study was undertaken to identify levels and patterns of genetic variability and resistance of tomato genotypes for resistant to
A. alternate
, and to apply markers for the identification of resistant lines in tomato breeding programs.

sec.title:
2.1. Disease severity evaluation of tomato genotypes caused by
A. alternata
sec.p:
The EB disease,
A. alternata
, severity analysis showed that all of the inoculated genotypes were infected under both greenhouse evaluation tests. The control plants (non-infected) were free of EB disease. In every growth stage, the inoculated genotypes exhibited varying severity responses to the disease ranging from 5 to 19% at transplanting stage and from 18 to 88% at maturing stage. These genotypes fell into 5 different categories in terms of the disease severity; highly susceptible (HS), susceptible (S), moderately susceptible (MS), moderately resistant (MR) and resistant (R). There was a significant difference in the percentage of the EB disease severity among tomato genotypes at transplanting and maturing stages (P < 0.01) ( Table 1 ).

At transplanting stage, EB disease screening of the inoculated tomato genotypes identified eight genotypes as resistant: H. a.s 2274, Esfahan local variety, Roma, Turkish Cherry, Valouro RZ , Long Tomato Y , Shiraz local variety and Falat American 111 (5â€“7%); the others were moderately resistant (8â€“20%). At maturing stage, the resistant genotypes were; Esfahan local, Turkish Cherry and Rio Grande (18â€“25%); the remaining genotypes varied in their response to the disease ranging from moderately resistant to highly susceptible (25â€“88%) ( Table 1 ).

The results showed that the greatest severity of the EB disease occurs mostly at the mature stage. The difference of EB disease severity was caused by genotype and growth stage; the interaction between these factors was significant at the 0.01 level. Overall, the results showed that H. a.s2274 and Esfahan local were resistant to
A . alternata
infection under both evaluation growth stages tests, while the majority of tomato genotypes varied from moderately to highly susceptible at both stages ( Table 1 ).

Cluster analysis of EB disease severity at both stages classified tomato genotypes into three main groups (I, II and III), which were consistent with the results of the LSD ( Fig. 1 ). The cluster results showed that the resistant tomato genotypes, Rio Grande, Turkish Cherry and Esfahan Local, belonged to the group (II), the highly susceptible tomato genotypes belonged to the group (III), and the moderately susceptible and moderately resistant belonged to group (I).

sec.title: 2.3. Comparative analysis of biochemical data
sec.p:
The results from the analysis of specific enzymatic activity and the total phenol content at both growth stages showed significant changes in most of the inoculated tomato leaves in comparison with the controls ( Tables 6 and 7 ). At the transplanting stage, there was a significant increase in the CAT activity among all tomato genotypes in comparison with the controls, but the highest increase was observed in Esfahan Local (65.58 Uâˆ™mg 1 ), H . a.s 2274 (53.42 Uâˆ™mg 1 ), Caribo (53.45 Uâˆ™mg 1 ) and Shiraz Local (47.43 Uâˆ™mg 1 ) ( Table 6 ). At the maturing stage, Esfahan Local and H . a.s 2274 had the highest CAT activity (106.98 and 79.46 Uâˆ™mg 1 respectively) ( Table 7 ). The transplanting stage showed an increased level of specific POD activity in response to
A. Alternata
infection, while the highest level was observed in the resistant genotypes, H . a.s 2274 (116.46 Uâˆ™mg 1 ) and Shiraz Local variety (97.76 Uâˆ™mg 1 ) as compared with the controls ( Table 6 ).

The level of specific POD activity at the maturing stage was higher in the inoculated resistant genotypes, H . a.s 2274, Turkish Cherry, Rio Grande and Esfahan Local variety (340.74, 311.92, 268.06 and 258.66 Uâˆ™mg 1 , respectively) in comparison with the controls ( Table 7 ).

Here again, the transplanting stage showed a higher level of specific PAL activity in the inoculated resistant genotypes, Shiraz Local variety (6.96 Uâˆ™mg 1 ), H . a.s 2274 (5.45 Uâˆ™mg 1 ) and Esfahan Local variety (4.65 Uâˆ™mg 1 ) in comparison with the controls and the susceptible genotypes ( Table 6 ). Similarly, there was a significant increase in the PAL activity among inoculated resistant genotypes at the maturing stage ( Table 7 ). In the transplanting stage, all inoculated resistant genotypes showed a significant increase in the SOD activity, but the highest level of activity was observed in Shiraz Local and Esfahan Local (4.45, and 3.63 Uâˆ™mg 1 , respectively) in comparison with others ( Table 6 ). In the maturing stage, increased SOD activity was seen in all the inoculated genotypes, but the highest level was observed in H . a.s 2274, Turkish Cherry and Esfahan Local (9.02, 8.08 and 6.29 Uâˆ™mg 1 , respectively) ( Table 7 ).

The transplanting stage showed a large amount of TPC in all inoculated tomato leaves ( 16â€“70 mg GAE/g f. wt) in comparison with the controls ( Table 6 ). The inoculated resistant genotypes, Shiraz Local, Esfahan Local and H . a.s 2274, contained much higher TPC (70.16, 69.25, 53.98 Uâˆ™mg 1 , respectively), than the susceptible genotypes ( Table 6 ). The level of TPC was significantly higher at the maturing stage in the infected plants in comparison with the controls ( 29â€“87 mg GAE/g f. wt). Esfahan Local, Turkish Cherry and H . a.s 2274 contained the highest value of TPC (87.62, 86.53 and 82.89, Uâˆ™mg 1 respectively) in comparison with the controls ( Table 7 ).

sec.title: 3. Discussion
sec.p:
According to our findings, only H . a.s 2274 and Esfahan local Variety were found to be resistant to
A. alternata
at both growth stages. The screening results of 172 recombinant inbred line population of tomato under field conditions by
showed a wide range of reactions in response to EB disease, from resistant to susceptible, and no lines were completely resistant.

While our study found an average number of 6.18 bands per primer,

The higher mean of the total bands as reported in these studies could be attributed to either the higher number of tomato genotypes or the higher number of primers. Notably, a significant increase in TPC values was seen in all tomato genotypes during
A. alternata
infection. Higher TPC values were seen in inoculated resistant genotypes at both growth stages. These results clearly showed the involvement of TPC in the defense of tomato to EB disease. The highest TPC activity at transplanting stage (4-fold) and maturing stage (2 to 3-fold) were found in all the inoculated resistant genotypes as compared with their respective controls. These findings are consistent with previous studies (
; w.
), that have reported high level of phenols acting as damaging components in
A. alternata
infection.

In conclusion, the present study furthers our understanding of the significance of antioxidants and the extent of genetic diversity in 35
S. lycopersicum
genotypes in response to
A. alternata
infection. Based on EB disease-resistance levels and ISSR marker data, the 35 tomato genotypes were categorized into five major groups. Among all the inoculated genotypes, H . a.s 2274 and Esfahan local showed a significant resistance level, and increased antioxidant activities at both growth stages. Moreover, enhancement of antioxidants and enzymes production in the EB disease-resistance in tomato genotypes are important observations. Future research is needed to examine the relationship between genetic diversity and EB disease-resistance.

sec.title: 4.3. DNA extraction and ISSR amplifications
sec.p:
Genomic DNA extraction from about 1 g of young leaf tissue (the 5â€“6 leaf stage) from each tomato genotype was carried out using a modified Cetyl Trimethyl Ammonium Bromide (CTAB) - based method according to
. The DNA quality and purity were determined using a Nano spectrophotometer. The PCR-based ISSR reaction mixes were prepared according to
using 15 ISSR primers (Macrogen Korea, South Korea ). The amplification reaction mix (25 Î¼L) comprised 1 Î¼L extracted DNA, 1.5 Î¼L of 1 primer, 12.5 Î¼L of 2x Master mix Red and 10 Î¼L distilled water (Ampliqon, Odense, Denmark ). The DNA amplifications were performed using an Eppendorf Gradient Mastercycler (Eppendorf, Hamburg , Germany ). Amplification reactions were programmed in a 10-m initial denaturalization phase at 94 â—¦ C followed by 45 cycles of annealing each lasting 45â€“60 s, at a primer-specific temperature ( Table 3 ). The process continued with an extension phase at 72 â—¦ C for 2 min and with a final extension phase at 72 â—¦ C for 10 min when naturalization occurs. The PCR-amplified fragments were electrophoresed on 1.5% (w/v) agarose gels, in the 1X TBE Buffer at 80 V for 1.5 h. A gene ruler 100 bp DNA ladder plus (RNA Biotech Co., Isfahan , Iran ) was used as a standard to determine size of polymorphic fragments, as visualized by ethidium bromide staining and photographed under UV light.

sec.title: 4.4. Antioxidant activities and total phenolic contents analysis
sec.p:
Estimations of defense-related enzyme contents were done on extracts. To obtain CAT, POD, PAL and SOD extracts, pre-weighed infected and non-infected leaves were homogenized in 4 mL buffer [50 mM Tris pH = 8.5, 14.4 mM 2-mercaptoethanol and 1% (w/v) insoluble polyvinylpolypyrrorolidone]. Homogenates were centrifuged at 6000Ã— g for 15 min at 4 â—¦ C (
